ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Became aware of a variety of primary source materials available on the Qing Dynasty. Obtained a grasp of bureaucratic phraseology.
I am exposed to many Qing documents, and Qing archives. I learnt about the necessary historical facts and ways to analyze them in this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Course overall was great. Perhaps more could have been done to limit presentation length, as some dragged on and took time away from going through course readings.

It has really achieved its goal, namely, to familiarize the students with Qing documents, to improve our translation skills, and to help us to critically analyze the materials. But I hope after translating each passage we might have more time for close reading and discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Would absolutely recommend to anyone with an interest in researching China from 17th century to present.
Yes, of course! It is a very good course in Qing history, and it would be helpful for students majoring in not only history but also literature and anthropology and sociology.
